fields.title: 8 Qualities of Highly Productive People
fields.description:
While the vast majority of the world’s population has probably never thought about increasing their performance or productivity, there is a group of people that is constantly striving for progress.

Wanting to perform better, get more done, deliver more results, succeed in many ways.

Those are probably the people who have read Tim Ferris’ 4-Hour Workweek, know Gary Vaynerchuk’s hustle mentality and are after building something bigger every day.

These people have a mission, something that is bigger than themselves. They are chasing to build something that has an impact on people’s lives.

At the same time, people with big dreams are the ones who are constantly working on optimizing themselves.

Building strong habits is one of the keys when talking about self-optimization.

    The right habits can help you to save time, energy and willpower.

Here are 8 Qualities of Highly Productive People:
1.) Cutting away the unimportant

Especially if you are an entrepreneur, you will know how important priorities are.

We are constantly faced with the challenge of deciding what to do and what to postpone or neglect.

    Highly productive people are doing great when it comes to focusing on the important.

I have recently published an article on the habits of happy people according to Warren Buffett and during my research, I came across Buffetts principle when it comes to setting priorities and focusing:

Buffetts 5/25 rule is a strategy to find out your own focus.

For this method, you just have to write down 25 things that you want to do and achieve in your life.

Next, you find your top five.

    Once you know, what your top five priorities are, you completely focus on them.

You forget the rest, you discard the other 20 ideas and possibilities and focus all your energy on your top five.

Another way to set priorities is the Eisenhower Matrix.

This is basically a chart where you can organize your tasks according to urgency and importance.

According to the Eisenhower Matrix you first focus on your tasks that are important and urgent, you schedule urgent but unimportant tasks, delegate important tasks that are not urgent and forget about all the rest.
2.) Allocate breaks strategically

Besides setting the right priorities, highly productive people also know when to schedule breaks.

Overworking and not caring for your own health cannot end up in satisfying results.

That’s why you always have to keep an eye on your health but also on your business to see if a break is needed.

    Sometimes, taking a break from the everyday business can be eye-opening and a great way to indicate new opportunities.

On the other side, also during your everyday work-life, you should schedule short breaks to ensure great productivity.

Moving your body, nourishing with great food and drinking lots of water is part of these breaks.

What also works wonders for me, when it comes to increasing my productivity is the Pomodoro Technique.

To make use of the Pomodoro Technique you set a timer to 25 minutes and focus on one task without any distraction.

Then you make a 5-minute break before again working without any distraction for 25 minutes.
3.) Remove all Productivity Killers

Nowadays we are surrounded by distractions all the time.

If you want to be highly efficient and productive, you have to get rid of any sort of distraction that might come into your way.

Especially, remove everything that is not work-related from your desk.

Turn off notifications.

Get rid of applications and other distracting pop-ups.

Prepare everything that you need to get your work done in advance so that you can perform effectively once you start with the work.
4.) Source of Inspiration
If we are honest, everybody has times when he is demotivated and needs some inspiration.

What differentiates highly productive people is that they have clear sources of inspiration that work for them.

This might be a walk outside, a vision board with all their goals and dreams or a quick talk to an important person.

How you exactly get motivated and inspired is not crucial.

    What is important, however, is that you have your own source of inspiration that you can come back to once you lack motivation.

5.) Don’t make yourself too accessible

Also here, I want to make use of a great article explaining how Warren Buffet explains the key to being successful.

If you are an entrepreneur, especially in the beginnings it can be tempting to join a lot of events, network and say yes to every opportunity that arises.

However, what differentiates highly productive people is that they don’t make themselves too accessible.

They focus on the relevant and on increasing their own performance.

Sure, collaborations and sometimes saying yes to a project can be a huge door opener, but if you say yes to everything and are too open, you will never be able to be in a state of high productivity on the long run.

6.) Optimizing Time Pockets
Highly productive people know how to make use of every minute.

There are so many opportunities to optimize the usage of free time throughout your day.

Even during your commute to work, while sitting in a waiting room or doing your groceries, you can use your time wisely.

My most favorite ways to make use of this spare time is educating myself through podcasts and audiobooks.

This way, I can consume high-quality content which is a great source of inspiration instead of losing time.

7.) Setting Timelines and Deadlines

If you are working on becoming more productive and efficient, timelines and deadlines must soon become your best friends.

Especially Parkinson’s Law is a concept that you will have to be aware of when it comes to increasing your productivity.

    Parkinson’s law is the adage that “Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion”.

Most people get overwhelmed by completing tasks and to-do’s because they work too much on the tiny details which are not necessarily important.

Increasing your productivity should definitely not mean delivering bad results, however, getting lost in the details and spending too much time with perfectionism can be your #1 productivity killer.

    Good is good enough.

8.) Automation
Last but not least, what highly productive people have in common is that they are constantly working on automating processes and workflows.

Once you know your goals and set up certain strategies on what needs to be done in order to achieve them there are many ways on how to optimize and automate your processes.

This can be done through outsourcing, delegation or simple automation through technology.

The easiest and cheapest way to outsource small tasks is to make use of freelancing platforms like Fiverr.

If you truly want to become more productive, take a look at your day and identify all the tasks that you work on, which you could automate.

Once you manage to automate those tasks, you can focus on things that have more impact on your projects, goals and yourself.The 7 Habits of Highly Productive People
The right habits can help you save time, energy, and willpower.
fields.summary:
Most people get overwhelmed by completing tasks and to-do’s because they work too much on the tiny details which are not necessarily important. Optimizing Time Pockets
Highly productive people know how to make use of every minute. If you truly want to become more productive, take a look at your day and identify all the tasks that you work on, which you could automate. Sometimes, taking a break from the everyday business can be eye-opening and a great way to indicate new opportunities. On the other side, also during your everyday work-life, you should schedule short breaks to ensure great productivity. Once you manage to automate those tasks, you can focus on things that have more impact on your projects, goals and yourself.The 7 Habits of Highly Productive People
The right habits can help you save time, energy, and willpower.

fields.title: 4 Habits That Will Dramatically Improve Your Productivity
fields.description:
If you want to seriously improve your productivity, your guiding principle should be: Less but better.

Most people who want to be more productive waste their time and energy on cheap productivity hacks and silly time management techniques.

Like the writer who spends hours reading articles and books about how to be a writer instead of sitting their butts in a chair and writing, it’s all too easy to get addicted to productivity porn—constantly tinkering with a never-ending stream of tips and tricks that may feel good in the moment, but it ultimately lead nowhere.

What you really need is better habits.

If you’re ready to get serious about becoming more productive, here are 4 psychologically-sophisticated habits that will dramatically boost your productivity and focus.
1. Stop fighting procrastination and learn to use it.

Everybody feels the urge to procrastinate — it’s how we respond to that urge that separates the wannabes from the truly productive.

The desire to procrastinate is normal, healthy even. It’s your mind expressing its natural desire for novelty and curiosity. And no matter how committed to a particular task or piece of work, you will occasionally feel the urge to put off getting to work in favor of something more immediately enjoyable or interesting.

    To stay productive, you must change the way you think about procrastination.

Often the people who struggle the most with procrastination have harsh, judgmental beliefs about what it means to even feel like procrastinating. And these beliefs come out in the form of negative self-talk toward themselves:

    What’s wrong with me?! Why can’t I just get my sh*t together and focus!
    There I go again… I wish I wasn’t such a procrastinator!
    Look at Tom. He’s such a machine. He just sits down and gets to work. I wish I was as disciplined as he is.

The trouble with all the judgmental negative self-talk is that it adds a second layer of negative emotion onto your experience: Instead of just feeling like you don’t want to work, you also feel ashamed or angry or disappointed in yourself.

Now the urge to procrastinate is even stronger because distracting yourself with some cheap pleasure or entertainment is also a quick way to avoid the negative feels that came from your nasty self-talk.

The way out of this vicious cycle is to fundamentally change the way you think about and respond to the urge to procrastinate:

    Simply observe and notice your urge to procrastinate. Also, watch for any thoughts and feeling that automatically spring up in response to it. This is called meta-cognition — thinking about your thinking. It’s beneficial because it slows you down and helps short-circuit the default behavior of negative self-talk or immediate distraction.
    Label and accept your urge to procrastinate non-judgmentally. Simply acknowledge that you are in fact feeling the urge to procrastinate. But distinguish for yourself that just because you feel the urge doesn’t mean you have to act on it.
    Validate the urge to procrastinate. Remind yourself that it’s normal and valid to feel like procrastinating. You can also tell yourself that everybody feels the urge to procrastinate and that you’re not alone. Finally, if it helps, remind yourself of a time when you successfully got to work despite feeling like procrastinating. This will increase your confidence and self-efficacy and make it more likely that you choose to get to work despite your desire to procrastinate.
    Invite your procrastination along for the ride. Literally tell your urge to procrastinate that you’re willing for it to stick around as you get to work. By approaching (rather than avoiding) the desire to procrastinate, you’re training your brain to see it as something neutral rather than a threat. This will help lessen its intensity in the future.

By habitually criticizing yourself for your tendency to procrastinate, you’re making it harder to resit and training your brain to treat it as something dangerous in the future — both of which make it that much harder to simply get to work.

    Instead of fighting with your procrastination, practice validating it and be willing to live with it.

2. Ruthlessly eliminate digital distractions.

It’s not all in your head. Often the biggest obstacles to genuine productivity are on our desks, in our pockets, or inside the browser on our computer.

If you’re the kind of person reading an article like this one on how to be more productive, you probably have an internal locus of control bias. Meaning, you like the idea that being more productive is something within you — how you think, how you behave, what you want, etc.

But often the biggest reason we procrastinate and lose focus is our environment, specifically, our digital environment:

    The Twitter notification that just dinged
    The email that just popped up on your desktop
    That new game you just installed on your phone yesterday

Losing focus doesn’t necessarily mean our willpower muscle was weak; it may simply mean that the distractions in your environment are strong. And that before you even have time to consider engaging your will-power or self-control muscle, your attention has already gravitated toward a distraction and you’ve lost focus.

    Willpower should only be a last resort. Better to design your environment so that you don’t need it in the first place.

Before you sit down to work, make sure you’ve done everything you can to make sure your environment is conducive to work and focus rather than distracting:

    Implement the 4:55 Drill. The 4:55 Drill is a little technique I use to eliminate distractions and help me dive right into my most important and creative work. Often, we end up procrastinating because of the prep work needed just to figure out what we should be working on. Digging around in our email for something is a great way to get sidetracked into the depths of the internet. Instead, at the end of each workday (hence the 4:55 Drill), take 5 minutes and get yourself organized for the following day. Decide on the one or two things you’d like to accomplish first thing and assemble everything you need now so that’s you can hit the ground running tomorrow morning.
    Quarantine your phone. Face it: as powerful and wonderful as smartphones are, they’re also our biggest source of procrastination and loss of focus. I suggest not even trying to resist them, and instead, turn them off and put them out of sight. When I sit down to do serious work, I power down my phone completely and put in out of sight in a drawer. This means that not only will I not get distracted by notifications, but the mere sight of my phone won’t even be there as a distraction. What’s more, knowing that it’s powered off, means that there’s a lot more friction to simply checking my email or twitter — I would have to spend the extra 30 seconds to power on my phone. Often this is enough friction to make that temptation unattractive.
    Turn your computer into a single-tasking machine. If you’re any kind of knowledge worker, chances are your work is primarily done on a computer — writing documents, drafting reports, assembling presentations, etc. Unfortunately for your productivity, your computer is capable of doing all sorts of other fun and interesting tasks. Try this: before you start working, close down every application, window, program, and service except for the one or two that are absolutely essential to your work. Make your computer into a tool that only does one thing, and you’ll be far less tempted to use it to do other things.

Most digital distractions shroud themselves in a cloak of harmlessness and usefulness. As a result, we allow them to linger while we work.

But underneath that shallow veneer are powerful forces pulling you toward distraction and procrastination. And if you exert all your energy trying to resist these distractions, you’re cutting into the energy that should be dedicated to doing your best, most creative work.

    Get ruthless about eliminating distractions during your most important work — especially digital distractions.

3. Cultivate a deep work routine.

Cal Newport coined the phrase deep work in his book of the same name and describes it like this:

    Professional activities performed in a state of distraction-free concentration that push your cognitive capabilities to their limit. These efforts create new value, improve your skill, and are hard to replicate.

Deep work is your mind in high-gear.

It’s when you are working at close to your full potential, producing creative, high-quality work in a way that’s efficient and prolific. It’s the holy grain of productivity.

The problem is, because it’s so mentally taxing, it’s very hard to do. And it’s extremely hard to do consistently. Which is where the term routine comes in…

Routines solve two big problems when it comes to deep work:

    You can’t just sit down and expect your mind to jump to 100% capacity and crank out an hour of highly-focused, creative work. You have to build up to it gradually. You need to train your mind to adjust to deep work, which is a very different way of operating than our standard, semi-distracted way of working.
    You need a system for keeping you consistent with your deep work. If you’re constantly being interrupted by coworkers or tempted to procrastinate by social media, you’ll never stay consistent with deep work.

A solid deep work routine solves both of these problems.

Here’s how to get started creating your own deep work routine:

    Decide on a consistent time for your deep work. Ideally, it’s a consistent time several days per week. First thing in the morning when I get to the office, for example. Whatever you chose, you must make that time sacred.
    Start small with a duration and gradually work up. Initially, I recommend doing deep work in 20-minute bursts. After a week or so, you can up it to 30 minutes. Ideal results tend to come when you can work in stretches of 45 to 60 minutes of focused, distraction free time.
    Ruthlessly eliminate distractions. See section #2 above. Importantly, it’s not enough to simply remove the distraction itself (e.g. Twitter notifications turned off). You should try your best to remove even the temptation to get distracted (e.g. leave your phone in your car or another room).
    Track progress and reward yourself. Create a simple tracking system to measure progress and reward yourself. I like the Seinfeld Strategy, which involves marking off days on a calendar after I’ve completed my deep work and trying not to “break the chain.” I also, reward myself for finishing by making a fancy cup of coffee afterward.

    Deep work is a productivity superpower. But to harness it, you need an airtight routine to stay committed.

4. Harness the power of forcing functions

A forcing function is a mechanism that forces you to take some kind of action. It’s the antidote to inconsistent willpower or motivation.

When a pop-up takes over your screen and asks if you want to save 50% on this month’s newest styles, it forces you into one of two decisions — click the big green “YES” button or spend 3 minutes hunting for the tiny, barely-visible “x” to close out of the popup.

Marketers and salespeople use forcing functions all the time to increase the odds that a potential customer becomes an actual customer. But forcing functions can be just as useful for personal productivity.

Suppose I really wanted to get this article done by Monday, but I kept procrastinating on writing it. I could write a check for $100 and make it out to my buddy Todd, telling him that if I hadn’t emailed him a completed draft of this article by Monday at 5:00 pm, he should immediately cash the check and buy himself something.

That’s a forcing function. By putting $100 dollars on the line, I’m forcing (or at least strongly encouraging) myself to follow through on my goals instead of getting distracted by short-term desires.

    Exceptionally productive people are masters of self-imposed forcing functions.

They have the humility to realize that distractions are prevalent, motivation sometimes wanes, and in general, we’re all a lot less disciplined than we’d like to be. So, instead of hoping for the best, they assume the worst and plan accordingly.

Here are a few good examples of forcing functions you can use to improve your productivity:

    If you want to get a lot of work done quickly, take your laptop but no charger and work at the coffee shop (hat tip: Dan Martell).
    If you want to get more work done in your home office, remove the TV and uninstall all apps from your computer that aren’t directly related to your work.
    Hire a coach and pre-pay for several months worth of sessions.
    Tell you assistant or spouse to change your social media passwords until beginning of each month and not tell you the new ones until you’ve completed a particular goal or project (hat tip: James Clear in Atomic Habits).

    Never rely on motivation. Design systems that incentivize you to do the work no matter how you feel.

All you need to know

If you want to dramatically improve your personal productivity stop fiddling around with trivial hacks and get serious about building rigorous habits to boost your motivation, concentration, and discipline:

Stop fighting procrastination and learn to validate it.

Ruthlessly eliminate digital distractions.

Cultivate a deep work routine.

Harness the power of forcing functions.
fields.summary:
Which is where the term routine comes in…

Routines solve two big problems when it comes to deep work:

    You can’t just sit down and expect your mind to jump to 100% capacity and crank out an hour of highly-focused, creative work. Make your computer into a tool that only does one thing, and you’ll be far less tempted to use it to do other things. Before you sit down to work, make sure you’ve done everything you can to make sure your environment is conducive to work and focus rather than distracting:

    Implement the 4:55 Drill. And no matter how committed to a particular task or piece of work, you will occasionally feel the urge to put off getting to work in favor of something more immediately enjoyable or interesting. All you need to know

If you want to dramatically improve your personal productivity stop fiddling around with trivial hacks and get serious about building rigorous habits to boost your motivation, concentration, and discipline:

Stop fighting procrastination and learn to validate it. You need to train your mind to adjust to deep work, which is a very different way of operating than our standard, semi-distracted way of working. Here’s how to get started creating your own deep work routine:

    Decide on a consistent time for your deep work. Here are a few good examples of forcing functions you can use to improve your productivity:

    If you want to get a lot of work done quickly, take your laptop but no charger and work at the coffee shop (hat tip: Dan Martell). By habitually criticizing yourself for your tendency to procrastinate, you’re making it harder to resit and training your brain to treat it as something dangerous in the future — both of which make it that much harder to simply get to work. But often the biggest reason we procrastinate and lose focus is our environment, specifically, our digital environment:

    The Twitter notification that just dinged
    The email that just popped up on your desktop
    That new game you just installed on your phone yesterday

Losing focus doesn’t necessarily mean our willpower muscle was weak; it may simply mean that the distractions in your environment are strong. Ideal results tend to come when you can work in stretches of 45 to 60 minutes of focused, distraction free time. Try this: before you start working, close down every application, window, program, and service except for the one or two that are absolutely essential to your work. I suggest not even trying to resist them, and instead, turn them off and put them out of sight.

fields.title: Help yourself by first helping others
fields.description:
“When we give cheerfully and accept gratefully, everyone is blessed.”
    ― Maya Angelou

Everyone needs help once in a while. We all find ourselves in a spot where we need to hold on to someone else’s hand in order for us not to drown. But receiving help is becoming extremely rare, very few people are willing to lend a hand.

We are living in an age where most of us are so busy with our lives that we have no time to help others. Can you blame us? We can barely deal with our own problems or keep up with the many distractions around us, how can we even think of helping someone else? Why even bother, right? Wrong.

When we do good to others and offer a helping hand, the recipients of our kindness aren’t the only ones reaping the benefits. The benefits of offering help also extend to the one giving the help. Among the hundreds of benfits that come with you helping others, five of them do stand out to me.

Allow me to share them with you.
Helping others will build better relationships for you.

The act of helping someone else is a positive act, it gives off a positive vibe to others. Others, who like everyone else, are weighed down with the world’s never ending negativity.

People are attracted to positive vibes.

This may improve your current relationships and create new ones with people who wish to have the same. A lot of people appreciate a helping hand in their hour of need and even though it may have not meant much to you, it may have meant the world to them and they would never forget it.

When you become a source of genuine help to your friends you can build life long bonds.
Helping others will make you feel empowered.

Empowered to do what?

To take on bigger tasks.

How so?

Well, helping someone out will leave you feeling rewarded and fulfilled. This rich feeling has the ability to provide you with the motivation, drive and purpose to do “more” with your life. What the “more” is is entirely up to you.
It helps you cultivate gratitude

Someone who needs help is lacking something, and if you can provide the help to that person then you have what he is lacking.

But we rarely see what other people are lacking unless we have an attitude that is willing to identify the areas in their life that the need help with.

When we help others and see what they might be lacking, we develop a sense of gratitude for the things we have.

I used to help my grandmother with her grocery shopping, she envied the young strength I had to swiftly move between aisles and grab her groceries. This showed me that even the strength that I have in my youth is something that I should be grateful for because someone out there does not have it and they really need it.

Helping others can give us a perspective on our own situation and teach us to be thankful for what we have.
Improves your self-confidence and self-esteem

The experience of helping others can lead to a sense of greater self-worth and confidence. The act of helping is a ‘good’ act. ‘Good’ acts fill you with a strong sense of self- worth, usually the greater the act the stronger your self-worth will be.

This has been noted in many people who do volunteer work.

Volunteering can provide you with a sense of purpose, especially in tough times. People who volunteer have been found to have higher self-esteem and overall well-being. Experts explain that as feelings of social connectedness increase, so does your self-esteem.

You may lack confidence in your abilities until you discover the countless ways you can enrich the lives of another. When you provide value to others, you gain confidence in your personal skills and intellect.
Helping others will help you to build a rich network

When you help someone a few times, you make them part of your network.
Networks connect us with resources; they can build us and help us when we are in need. Networks empower us. The more people you help the larger your network becomes.

I still remember the person who helped me deliver my very first resume to his friend who was a human resource manager at a certain company. That act which may have seemed so simple to him landed me my first job which enabled me to be able to pay for my exam fees and complete education. I will never forget that. We were not friends before that but now we are.

Helping others will make you grow a network that will provide even greater help to you than you may have anticipated.
Conclusion

We should not be in the habit of turning people away when we can help them. Rather we should be looking for ways to ease the burden of others. It does not necessarily have to be huge acts, even small acts which we may take for granted may be life changing to them

When we offer to help someone else, they benefit. But so do we. Sometimes a lot more than them.

Do you know of any other benefits that you have received from helping others? Share them in the comment section below.
fields.summary:
A lot of people appreciate a helping hand in their hour of need and even though it may have not meant much to you, it may have meant the world to them and they would never forget it. It does not necessarily have to be huge acts, even small acts which we may take for granted may be life changing to them

When we offer to help someone else, they benefit. But we rarely see what other people are lacking unless we have an attitude that is willing to identify the areas in their life that the need help with. When we help others and see what they might be lacking, we develop a sense of gratitude for the things we have. We can barely deal with our own problems or keep up with the many distractions around us, how can we even think of helping someone else?

fields.title: Step By Step Guide on “How To Motivate Yourself To Do The Impossible Like A Pro?”
fields.description:
Most of us always try to find answers to this question “How to motivate yourself and stay motivated?”

Haven’t you?

I believe that’s what you are here for 🙂

Not just that, people from different areas of life ask it in their own versions like…

Students ask “How to motivate yourself to study?”

Teachers ask “How to motivate students?”

Fitness enthusiasts ask “How to motivate yourself to work out?”

Those who want to lose weight ask “How to motivate yourself to lose weight?”

Professionals ask “How to stay motivated at work?”

Employers ask “How to motivate employees?”

And so on…

This means people like you and I, feel that motivation is important. Therefore, you might ask yourself ‘how can I motivate myself to change my life’.
Why Motivation Is Important To Anyone?

It is because most of the people believe that motivation is important to maintain consistency and ultimately succeed in any endeavor of life.

It helps to increase your productivity, level of efforts and get through tough times.

It also makes your journey more fun and helps to influence others too.

But there is one major problem with motivation…

You must have faced that. It doesn’t last long.
Why Motivation Sucks?

Motivation doesn’t last and that’s why people ask “How to stay motivated?”

Motivation is like a quick sugar rush. You get that spike and feel on top of the world. And after some time..poof!!! You are back to square one.

You must have thought about how you can stay motivated throughout the day, week, month, year or your entire life.

This is the mistake you and I do. Motivation is just like taking your another meal or bathing.

You need it on a regular basis. We’ll discuss it in the upcoming section in the article.

But if motivation cannot push you through then what?

More than motivation, you need a system or routine in place that can ensure that you stay motivated and get things done which are important to you.

How to keep yourself motivated?

Here are 4 steps that you can implement in your life to create a pull rather than pushing yourself.
How To Motivate Yourself To Do The Impossible?
1. Setting Up The Right Foundation For A Long Term Game
Unleash The Biggest ‘WHY’“

He who has a WHY to live can bear almost any how.” ~Fredrick Nietzsche

Remember a time, when you had to prepare for a job interview, you had a deadline to meet, or your loved one was in need.

Weren’t you super-productive at that time?

Did you need anything else to motivate you to work?

Why was it so?

Because you had a clear purpose, a Big WHY!

But we rarely create a Big WHY for our daily routine and that’s the major reason why people search for motivation from the outside. If you can give the same sense of purpose to your daily life, believe me, you are set to do wonders.

Learn how to find your purpose and passion in life, it will help you push through any kind of challenges.
How To Find The Biggest WHY?

For that you need to ask multiple “Whys” to reach the ultimate root, the big-enough reason which can drive you. That big-enough reason which is impossible for you to ignore.

It is like an onion. You peel off the layers one by one till you reach the core.

Ask at least 5 Whys.

Contemplate about it, find top 3 reasons, write it down in your journal, make it your wallpaper in your cellphone/laptop, or stick it on the wall of your room.

Keep it at a place where you can see it frequently and etch it across your mind.

[Pro Stuff: I have created an audio tool that you can use to find your Biggest WHY. Get instant access for free]

If you are able to find that one big-enough reason, it will have the ability to take you through any kind of challenge and the toughest of times.

If you really want to motivate yourself and stay motivated, you need a big enough “WHY”, because it is going to be tough, uncomfortable and painful, otherwise you might quit mid-way.

Once you have that big-enough reason, it will push you through any kind of adversity and you will succeed.

If you want to explore more about how to find your WHY, you can read this book “Find Your Why” by Simon Sinek.
Follow Your Biggest Rituals“

Rituals define us. All the results in your life come from a standard. And then you follow the standard up with rituals.” ~Tony Robbins

As discussed earlier, motivation won’t take you far but a well-set system will.

Establishing certain rituals or habits into your life will ensure that you make progress on your goals and passion.

Bryan, CEO Founder of PhCreative, shares in his article on Inc.com how some of the world’s most successful people like Steve Jobs, Tony Robbins, Oprah kick start their day with amazing morning rituals.

Rituals prepare you not for the good times but for the tough times so that you stay strong and keep moving in the direction of your vision and dreams.

Anybody can work in favorable circumstances, but when things go wrong, when the going gets tough, it is the power of your rituals which will push you through.

That’s the power of habit.

But how will you find out which habits to develop or rituals to start with?

So, I’m making this easier for you.

Here’s a simple framework you can use to identify your rituals or success habits. It is from my Amazon Best Selling Book ‘Rewire for Massive Success’.

It is called P.M.P.
P — Physical Fitness Ritual
“Take care of your body. It’s the only place you have to live.” ~Jim Rohn

You need to take care of your physical well-being because this is the only asset you have. This is one of the main ingredient for your success. There are a lot of benefits of regular exercise.

Any practice or activity which keeps you physically fit and active can be your physical fitness ritual. There could be a number of activities which you can choose from.

To name a few, these could be jogging, yoga, cycling, gym, playing sports, walking, rope skipping, etc.

Select an activity that suits you, your body, and your daily routine.

Devote at least 30–45 Mins every single day for this ritual, either morning or evening, but do it religiously.

It will not only make you physically fit and energetic, but will also increase your productivity throughout the day.

I won’t be explaining much as a lot of information is already available about it on the internet and various books.

I read this one book and incorporated some of the tips which I found very effective. It’s “The Athlete in You” by Kinita Kadakia Patel, an award-winning sports nutritionist who works with leading sports teams, organizations, and schools.

You can also check out her blog for more information about how nutrition plays a crucial role in maintaining your overall fitness.
M — Mental Fitness Ritual

“The mind is just like a muscle — the more you exercise it, the stronger it gets and the more it can expand.” ~Idowu Koyenikan

This ritual is about keeping your mind relaxed and calm. It is as important as your physical fitness.

Both are interlinked. If you feel physically good, your state of mind will also become better and if you’re mentally relaxed, you will feel more energy in your body.

It is a balance between the two that you need to maintain.

For this, you don’t need to do something extraordinary. You just need to spend some time with your own self during the day. If you can do that in the morning, it will be great. I’ll share some of the activities which you can try. For this, devote at least 15–20 minutes.

• Meditation

• Mindfulness practice

• Sitting quiet and introspect:

And when you do this exercise, journal your experiences and whatever insights you get.

I found this massive guide on how to practice mindfulness by S.J. Scott. If you want to learn more about Mindfulness Practice, you can check it out.
P — Power Booster Ritual

Or you can also call it your ‘Daily dose of motivation’.

As discussed earlier, that motivation doesn’t last long. Like you have to take your meals at regular intervals, similarly, take your dose of motivation.

Power Booster Ritual is something which gives you an instant boost. It motivates you and fills you with the energy to take on anything. It is something that touches your heart, shakes you up a bit and re-energizes you to take action.

What I used was a compilation of various talks.

For you, it could be your favorite talk, song, poem, motivational speech, some inspirational audio, story, etc.

Choose such audio to which when you listen, it goes deep in your heart and gives you goosebumps.

It thrills you and gives you hope that you can do anything you wish to do.

It must be something that helps you throw away your fears and limiting beliefs. It must give you a positive mindset.

If you try to recall, you must have listened to at least one such audio which makes you feel this way.

That one song from your childhood memories which still brings a smile on your face no matter what kind of mess you are in.

You must have heard that one story which inspires you to the highest level.

You must have listened to at least one such speaker whose speech had touched your soul and you had said, ‘Wow!’

Why wait for such tools to motivate yourself by coincidence?

Why not use them to motivate yourself each day, so that you never run out of that amazing energy?

Thoughtfully select such audio and listen to it every single day.

You can listen to it while you are working out.

Or listen to it while you travel.

Or listen to it when you wake up.

Or listen to it before you sleep.

Choose a time and listen to it at least 2–3 times a day, initially. Within 1 month, you will see the magic happening.

2. How To Boost Your Self Confidence To Get Through Daily Struggles Of Life?
Once you are able to identify your WHY and establish some kinds of rituals or habits into your life, it becomes relatively easier to stay motivated for your goals.

In your daily life, you will face many struggles which might lower your motivation level and you don’t wish to continue.

It happens with everyone. It happens with me too, till today.

How you can overcome that?

If you’ll ask me how do I overcome that on a daily basis, then…

below are some of the practices I follow to reduce the impact of such distractions.
Declutter to Stay Laser Focused

“Don’t ever let somebody tell you, you can’t do something. Not even me. You got a dream, you gotta protect it. People can’t do somethin’ themselves, they wanna tell you, you can’t do it. If you want somethin’, go get it. Period.” ~Most famous quote from movie “The Pursuit of Happyness”

These distractions could be useless activities you do, toxic people in your life or your own limiting thoughts. Identify those distractions and remove them brutally. It will help you remain laser focused.

Removing such distractions from your life is the best way to stay focused and increase productivity.

For removing limiting thoughts and toxic people from your mind, you can do this activity.

[Pro Stuff] Take out a piece of paper from your journal and write down: • All the fears, negative thoughts and situations that you have faced at some point or the other in your life and you had to struggle with them the most • Name of persons who always pull you down, stop you from moving forward and induce negative energy, no matter what you do -People who always thrust their opinions on you about what you can or cannot do -People who try to judge your capabilities and put labels on you Just write that down on a piece of paper, all of it. Take a couple of minutes to think and write it. Pick this paper in your hands, close your eyes and visualize all of that you have written in front of your eyes. Bring all the anger in you with which you would like to remove all those distractions out of your life. What would you want to do when you are super angry with someone?

Imagine slapping, punching, and shouting. With that level of anger, just tear down the paper into pieces. Tear it down into the tiniest of the pieces with all the anger and energy you have. Imagine kicking all that out of your life permanently. Phew! Done it? Great!

How are you feeling right now? Observe the change you have in your energy and willpower.

Assimilate it. Let it percolate deep inside you. Keep this attitude to deal with such distractions in your life and protect your growth and dream.

Other distractions you need to remove from your life are the activities which take away your precious time on a daily basis.

For removing such activities, you need to be aware of where you spend your time. At least at the end of the day, revisit your day and make a note of activities where you spent your time.

And such distractions happen especially when you are including something new into your life.

Suppose, you are installing a new habit to jog every day. What kind of distractions can prevent your change to be sustainable and how you can protect it?

You might have distractions from your friends, you might be abstaining from waking up early in the morning due to laziness or you might be sleeping late at night because you were busy watching TV series or movies on your laptop, or had spent a lot of time on social media checking out what your friends are up to. You might be taking a very heavy meal before you sleep.

What are these?

These are nothing but the pests which will eat away the seed of change you want to sow in your life. Due to these pests, you won’t be able to continue your new habit to jog in the morning.

These distractions bring your motivation level down.

Then most of the people quit.

If you really want your change to be permanent and fruitful, you need to identify such harmful elements and ruthlessly throw them away.

These distractions happen in a moment. You just have to take care of those moments. The action you take in that particular moment will either boost your energy or drain it further. So, just take the right action in that moment.
>> When you think of hitting the snooze button in the morning to get that extra 15 minutes of sleep, choose to get up from the bed.

>> When you feel the craving to blame someone else and feel good, then take the onus on yourself, take the responsibility and move forward.

>> When you are tempted to check your smartphone to see how many likes or comments you have got on your recently uploaded pics, keep your phone away and focus on something more important.

>> When your friend asks you to eat something which is not according to the diet you have chosen for yourself, say no.

>> When someone ridicules your dreams and passion which lets you feel inferior about yourself, just ignore it and move on.

There can be a number of such moments in your daily life by which you get distracted, waste your time and energy, and move away from your path, which tends to eat away your seed of change.

It’s YOU who has to decide what to do at that moment because only you can do that. Only you have that power with you until you give that control to someone else.
Keep the Entry Barrier Low

Start small to build self-confidence, self-esteem and feel good about yourself.

It will not only help you to motivate yourself but also stay motivated every single day. There is magic in starting small.

The biggest mistake I did when I started working for my health and fitness, I expected too much.

I planned that I would wake up at 5 am and work out for 1–2 hour.

Imagine a situation, when you have not done any such thing in the past and suddenly you plan to do it.

What will happen?

You may or may not be able to do it. And when you fail, what happens?

You get demotivated and you stop doing it.

But when you keep your entry barrier very low, you start to make progress and build self-confidence gradually. So, keep it as low as possible and gradually increase the level.

It will help you to maintain continuity, motivation and your hunger for more.

For example: if you have to start a daily routine of exercise or gymming, start with a small 5–10 minutes of body stretches each day for 20–30 days.

When you are able to continue that, increase the time and level of exercise you do.

You can apply this logic anywhere in your life and become better with time.
Progress Each Day To Build Momentum

Consistency is another crucial thing that you need to care about.

Make progress every single day. No matter how small it is, it will help you become better each day.

While working on my blog, it happens with me too, that on some day, I’m not able to do a lot of work due to various reasons.

Therefore, I make sure that I do something every day, even if it is a very small task like searching for a new topic for future articles, sharing my article link to Facebook groups, writing a small piece, making some changes in my blog, updating my existing article, etc.

Gustavo Razzetti, CEO @ liberationist.org, explains the power of making progress every single day in his article on The Ten Percent Advantage: How to Make Progress Every Day.

Making progress every day helps me to stay connected and look at myself with confidence. It keeps me in the game and I feel motivated to do more.

But if you break that consistency, after some days you will lose interest and you will be more likely to quit.

If you are doing a full-time job, working on your passion with a job could be a daunting task and sometimes you will not feel like doing it.

Sometimes, you might have planned for a 3 hours slot to work on your passion but you are left with just one hour because you got late or you simply wasted your time in relaxing for too long or some useless activity.

Now the choice is with you, either to waste that one hour you are left with by repenting on the two hours wasted or just get up and make some progress in that one hour.

You will come across such situations a many times, no matter whether you are working a full-time job, a student, a homemaker or a freelancer.

Whenever it happens, you need to handle it wisely.

Remember, some progress is always better than no progress at all. It helps in building momentum on a daily basis.
Look Back And Remind Yourself Why You Started

Here is how your biggest WHY helps you.

Whenever you feel low on motivation and find yourself clueless, remind yourself of your biggest WHY for which you started in the very first place.

The bigger your why will be, the easier it will be for you to overcome such phases.

Even I face such situations, then I revisit my biggest WHY and it pumps me up with new energy.
3. How To Handle Failures And Setbacks To Bounce Back?

Make Up Your Mind

Setbacks or failures should not be surprises for you.

When you start working on something, understand that you might face a failure too and that should not be a shock for you.

Make up your mind how you are going to handle your setbacks so that when it comes, it is not a surprise for you and you know how to get through this.

It is not about making a Plan B or doubting your capabilities. Sometimes, there could be circumstances due to which you might fail. But you have to decide how you are going to respond to it.

It is about understanding that even if you fail, that will be an opportunity to learn. That is how you have to make up your mind.
Be Gentle, Kind And Compassionate Towards Yourself

The first thing you do when you fail is to curse yourself. Please don’t do it.

Nobody makes an attempt to fail, everybody wants to succeed. And you too did it to succeed.

It’s fine if you failed. Be gentle to yourself. Show some compassion for yourself. Appreciate that you tried.

Take this time to revisit and find what went wrong. Learn from it, improve it and give another attempt.
4. How To Handle Success To Rise Even Higher?
Be Grateful

When you achieve success in whatever you are doing, be grateful to whatever you believe in.

It’s easy to get carried away and become arrogant but it won’t help you. Success must bring humility, not arrogance.
Success Might Feel Different From How You Thought Of

Sometimes, success doesn’t feel the way you thought about it.

When I wrote my book ‘Rewire for Massive Success’, I had put a lot of efforts to make it best selling book on Amazon. I thought when it will happen, I’ll be happy and it will be a great achievement.

But when my book finally became Amazon Best Seller after a continuous struggle of more than one year, the feeling wasn’t the same as I expected. I felt the rush for some time but then I felt clueless.

For a couple of months, I struggled and kept asking myself “So what?”, “What next?”

It took me some time to figure out what to do next. And then I came up with this blog ‘Selfhelpiness.com’ with a much bigger vision. I also developed a new concept of Selfhelpiness Quotient so that one can look beyond IQ and EQ. (Check out your SQ if you haven’t)

Success comes with excitement and immediately leaves you in a dip if it is based on some external factor.

It’s like an amazing party night you had with friends and the next day you are in a hangover. Eventually, you will be successful in whatever you are doing but the more difficult part is when you get it, how to build on that.

And you will not be able to do that unless you have your goals beyond materialistic things. Your goals, your passion must be intrinsic.

The more you are connected to your inside, the more stable you will be.
Summary

Don’t rely on motivation by chance. Use it like bathing or having your meals.

Prepare a system or routine for yourself where it becomes your habit to stay motivated and consistently improve at whatever you are doing.

Declutter your mind and your life in order to save your time and energy, and even your money.

Start small, make progress every single day and remind yourself your biggest WHY.

Learn to handle failures as well as successes.

Be kind to yourself, show some compassion and keep getting better at your craft. No matter how small is your progress, keep doing it.
Freebies With This Guide
A Small Request

If you found this guide on “How to motivate yourself and stay motivated?” useful, please share it with people who might need it. It will help me to reach out to more people and bring some positive change in their life.

Even one share will mean a lot to me 🙂

And don’t forget to share your thoughts in the comment section on what you think about motivation, what kind of problems you face and where do you need my help. I’ll do my best to help you out.

Have a great day!
fields.summary:
Even one share will mean a lot to me 🙂

And don’t forget to share your thoughts in the comment section on what you think about motivation, what kind of problems you face and where do you need my help. Get instant access for free]

If you are able to find that one big-enough reason, it will have the ability to take you through any kind of challenge and the toughest of times. [Pro Stuff] Take out a piece of paper from your journal and write down: • All the fears, negative thoughts and situations that you have faced at some point or the other in your life and you had to struggle with them the most • Name of persons who always pull you down, stop you from moving forward and induce negative energy, no matter what you do -People who always thrust their opinions on you about what you can or cannot do -People who try to judge your capabilities and put labels on you Just write that down on a piece of paper, all of it. Making progress every day helps me to stay connected and look at myself with confidence. Setting Up The Right Foundation For A Long Term Game
Unleash The Biggest ‘WHY’“

He who has a WHY to live can bear almost any how.” ~Fredrick Nietzsche

Remember a time, when you had to prepare for a job interview, you had a deadline to meet, or your loved one was in need. More than motivation, you need a system or routine in place that can ensure that you stay motivated and get things done which are important to you. No matter how small it is, it will help you become better each day. Whenever you feel low on motivation and find yourself clueless, remind yourself of your biggest WHY for which you started in the very first place. Anybody can work in favorable circumstances, but when things go wrong, when the going gets tough, it is the power of your rituals which will push you through. If you really want to motivate yourself and stay motivated, you need a big enough “WHY”, because it is going to be tough, uncomfortable and painful, otherwise you might quit mid-way. Make up your mind how you are going to handle your setbacks so that when it comes, it is not a surprise for you and you know how to get through this. While working on my blog, it happens with me too, that on some day, I’m not able to do a lot of work due to various reasons. If you try to recall, you must have listened to at least one such audio which makes you feel this way. But we rarely create a Big WHY for our daily routine and that’s the major reason why people search for motivation from the outside. If you can give the same sense of purpose to your daily life, believe me, you are set to do wonders. Learn how to find your purpose and passion in life, it will help you push through any kind of challenges. When you start working on something, understand that you might face a failure too and that should not be a shock for you. In your daily life, you will face many struggles which might lower your motivation level and you don’t wish to continue. If you are doing a full-time job, working on your passion with a job could be a daunting task and sometimes you will not feel like doing it. Other distractions you need to remove from your life are the activities which take away your precious time on a daily basis. Rituals prepare you not for the good times but for the tough times so that you stay strong and keep moving in the direction of your vision and dreams. There can be a number of such moments in your daily life by which you get distracted, waste your time and energy, and move away from your path, which tends to eat away your seed of change. It will help me to reach out to more people and bring some positive change in their life. Motivation doesn’t last and that’s why people ask “How to stay motivated?”

Motivation is like a quick sugar rush. You just need to spend some time with your own self during the day. Eventually, you will be successful in whatever you are doing but the more difficult part is when you get it, how to build on that.

fields.title: 6 Easy Steps to Find Your Passion in Life
fields.description:
Whenever I talk to people about my passion, I get showered with questions like these:

How to find your purpose and passion in life?

How do I find my passion?

How to find what’s your calling?

Is there a step by step guide to find your passion?

Is there a test or quiz to find your passion?

Is there a book about how to find your passion?

How to find your passion and make it your career?

How to find what you love to do?

How to find your calling?

……..

…..

…

And so on. Such questions are never ending! Everyone is so crazy about how to find your purpose and passion in life.

I love public speaking, writing and helping others to become their better version. And this is not something that I got enlightened with one fine day.

It is something I have developed over a period of time by experimenting and exposing myself to new things in life.

Finding my passion has been a wonderful journey and I’m still exploring and evolving.
Why You Should Find Your Purpose and Passion in Life?

Before you start your journey of how to find your purpose and passion in life, you must ask these questions to yourself:

Why should you find your passion?

Why is it important for you to find your passion?

You might think that it will make your life easier because you’ll no longer have to go to a job you hate.

Most of the people think that if you know how to find your purpose and passion in life, it will make their life easier. But it’s seldom true.

Most of the entrepreneurs end up working for more than 80 hours a week after leaving their 40 hours a week job. And the interesting thing is that they are happy to do that.

Sometimes that even takes a toll on their personal life, health, and relationships too. But they still do it.

WHY?

Because…

They do it to make their life worthwhile and meaningful.

They are interested in creating a much bigger impact not just in their own life but for others too.

Passion + Daily Action = Meaningful Life

And if you’ll ask me if there is some perfect recipe for how to find your purpose and passion in life, the answer is a BIG NO!

But is it possible to find your passion or find what you love to do?

The answer is YES!

Because discovering your passion, is something which you will have to do all by yourself.

When you choose to self-introspect and are open to experimentation with your life…

When you are ready to do unconventional things and learn new skills…

…there are greater chances that you will be able to find what you love to do.

But, if you will wait for a perfect time, for someone to reveal your passion to you…

…I doubt if such a moment will ever come 🙂

If you ask me, I’ll share ways that worked for me and helped me to find my passion in life.

And I’m glad that it can be turned into a profession (thought that’s a discussion for some other time).

So…
1. Take a PAUSE to Reflect (P)
The biggest reason why you might not be able to find your passion or calling is that you are constantly busy with your routine life…

…and never took a break to think for a moment from where you are coming and where you are heading in life.

Have you?

If you look at your life, you’ll find that most of the time you are distracted due to various reasons…

…sometimes it may be your phone, calls, emails, TV shows or stupid opinions of others.

If you really want to know how to find your purpose and passion in life, you’ll need to do something about it.

These distractions take away the most valuable thing you have, your focus and your time.

You think you are busy, but you are just distracted.

You spend your valuable time and focus on things which don’t add value to your life.

So, stop giving a f*ck about things that don’t matter, as Mark Manson tells in his book.

If you can take some time off from all of your daily distractions and spend some time with yourself…

…you’ll be able to explore a whole new world for yourself

…you’ll be able to find your passion,

…you’ll be able to find your calling,

…you’ll be able to find your purpose in life.

Suggested Reading: The Subtle Art of Not Giving A F*Ck

In order to take a pause to reflect on your life, you need to cut away all kinds of distractions at least once a day for at least 20–35 minutes.

Switch off your phone and any other thing that can take away your attention.

Indulge in something that soothes you and shifts your awareness inward.

You can try activities like…

    Mindfulness meditation
    Take a walk in a nearby park
    Observe nature

When you take such pauses, observe your life from a third person perspective,

…examine where you are, connect the dots from your past and see where you are headed,

…observe what are your fundamental values and beliefs on which you operate.

When you do this exercise on regular basis, you’ll have more clarity about yourself and you’ll be more SELF AWARE.

Clarity and Self Awareness are the basic ingredients to find your purpose and passion in life.

While doing this activity, whatever comes to your mind, just write it down in your journal.

Oh! I forgot to ask. Do you have a JOURNAL??

If not, then you must have one. It will be a great tool for you on your journey of finding your purpose and passion.

2. ASK Questions to Bring Clarity (A)
To find your purpose and passion in life, ask some questions to yourself which will help in bringing some clarity.

You can try it now.

Take a moment and ask these simple questions to yourself, right now!

Grab your journal (or a paper) and pen, write down your answers to these questions.

Where do you spend most of your time and money, especially on holidays?

What kind of content do you consume in the form of videos, blogs, and books?

What your friends reach out to you for, most of the time?

What did you love to do when you were a kid?

What makes you happy even if it is tough to do and you can even forget to eat?

What would you do if money didn’t matter?

What would you spend your time doing, if you had the complete financial abundance to do anything?

Don’t be so selective about the answers, whatever comes to your mind, just write it down.

I do this exercise whenever I find myself a bit lost.

When I answered these questions for myself, I got insights like these:

I spend most of my time reading books, blogs and watching videos on self-improvement, human behavior, and psychology.

I spend money to buy books and online courses on similar topics. And my sweet wife always complains about it 😉

I love to write about my experience and because of that, I was able to publish my book too. Fortunately, it became #1 Amazon Best- Selling Book in Coaching & Training category within a couple days of launch. This book has my journey of going through the toughest phase of my life and discovering my passion and purpose for life, my calling. You can check it out here. 🙂

Over the years, I have realized that my friends use to ask me about how to deal with situations, people and their own mindsets. That’s what I have been doing since I was in college.

And that’s what I love doing. Some people call it counseling and some call it coaching. But that’s something really excites me.

As a kid, I used to stand on my bed (using it as a stage) and speak as if I was delivering a speech in front of an audience.

My friends and family would sit around to listen to me.

I don’t exactly remember what I used to speak, but it was fun and all of them used to enjoy it.

Because of that, I started participating in public speaking competitions at school and fortunately, won some accolades too 🙂

Writing articles, interacting with people, conducting workshops, promoting my blog and spending quality time with my family, is what makes me really happy.

Although I’m still doing a 9 to 5 job, even then I’m able to do so many additional things because it makes me happy and keeps me excited.

Similarly, you can reflect upon your life and find out answers to the above questions.

This will help in understanding how you can find your purpose and passion in life.
3. REMEMBER, You are Mortal, to look at a Bigger Picture (R)
Remember you are mortal and can be gone at any moment.

Sorry, for saying it. But it’s the universal truth.

This might be intimidating but it’s true.

You might love to plan your entire life as if you are going to live forever but that’s not the case.

The sooner you realize it, the better you will be.

This life is very fragile and we don’t know when we are gone forever.

People think too much, hold grudges, plan everything meticulously, accumulate so many things, believing they are not going to die.

This human body has an expiry date too.

Therefore, whatever life You and I are left with, must be spent to make it meaningful and joyful.

Try to look at the bigger picture of your life

If you can look at the bigger picture, you’ll understand why it is important to find your purpose, your passion, your calling in life.

It is very easy to get carried away with your emotions or situations and make bad decisions in life.

If you are in confusion about something right now…

…fast forward your life 30–40 years and see if it still matters to you. Then decide what you need to do.

Therefore, try to add more and more experience to your life. Make it blissful.

Get as much as exposure as possible.

And how can you do that?

The best way is to Read and Interact as much as you can.

    Invest time in reading stuff related to your interest and explore.
    Read blogs, books, autobiographies, magazines…
    Meet new people who have similar interest. Go to meetups and clubs like Toastmasters.
    Talk to them. Understand how they look at things and how they work on their passion.
    You don’t need to copy them, just imbibe the good practices they follow.

It will give you an opportunity to widen your horizon of thinking, it will give you more perspective and new angles to look at the same situation.

It will give you exposure and open doors to new possibilities.

And you will understand that the world is much bigger than what you had thought.

Your adversities, challenges, and struggles will start to look smaller.

And the first thing you can do to make your life meaningful is by fueling your curiosity about how to find your purpose and passion in life.
4. FEEDBACK from Friends to Discover Your Natural Talents (F)
Off recently, I was doing this online course on “Personal Branding Mastery” on Udemy.

During that course, I had to do one exercise. Initially, I was reluctant because it pushed me to become a bit vulnerable to accepting feedback.

I didn’t know what people were going to tell about me.

The exercise had some questions which I had to ask my friends and colleagues in order to know what my skills and qualities are, from their perspective.

Also, get feedback on areas I need to make an improvement.

But when I did this exercise…

I got some incredible insights that I never thought about myself. That proved really helpful and I’m thankful to people who took out time to respond to the questionnaire.
And once you are through this exercise, let me know how do you feel after getting responses 🙂

It’s exciting and an eye-opener too.

Based on the exercise, you will be able to uncover some of the qualities and skills which can shape your passion.

That will help you have some clues about how to find your purpose and passion in life.

5. ACT & Experiment to Find Your Passion (A)
Act, experiment and correct the course as you move ahead.

Passion is not something that you’ll realize about it in your dreams and the next day you start working on it.

Passion is developed and evolved over a period of time. You experiment with several things and evaluate your experience.

You might find yourself changing from one interest to another over time. And that’s completely fine.

Don’t presume that your passion should be your job or you’ll have to quit your job to find your passion. That’s not true.

Finding passion is not always about getting into a profession you love. Passion is spending your time doing something which is close to your heart.

It may become your profession or something which you do by taking out time apart from your profession.

But the crux is, you’ll have to act and be ready to experiment with things you do in your life.

Experimentation is one of the best ways to find your purpose and passion in life.

Your passion will not come to you just by sitting on the couch, sipping drinks and watching Netflix.

You will have to spend some time every single day to explore new things and experiment.

Here are some examples:

    If you think traveling is something that excites you, then you’ll have to start researching about a place and pick up your backpack to travel on this coming weekend
    If you think cooking re-energizes you, get into the kitchen and start preparing your unique recipe
    If you think playing football is great, then stop watching a football game on TV, call up your friends and plan a match on this coming weekend
    If you think writing is your passion, pick up a question you would like to answer and start writing about it right away
    If you think playing Guitar is really awesome, then stop dreaming about it. Find the nearest music classes, call up, enroll and start attending classes from this week
    If you think dancing is something very close to your heart, then find the nearest dancing classes or club and join it right away
    If you want to explore something new, list down good books on that topic and start reading them one by one. List down names of people who have knowledge in that area and start meeting them one by one

There could be ’n’ number of such examples but the core message is the same.

Stop just dreaming.

Stop asking for secrets of how to find your purpose and passion in life 🙂

Act right now and take the next step.

By doing this, will you find your passion?

Maybe, Yes!. Maybe, No!

BUT!

You’ll be at least one step closer to finding your passion.

Taking such steps will make you a Doer.

You’ll no longer stay entangled in your thoughts.

Even if you don’t find happiness in doing what you thought could be your passion, you’ll at least come to know that it’s not your passion.

Otherwise, you would have kept on dreaming your entire life or maybe regretting that you never tried.

Take actions even if they are small.

Let your passion evolve with time.

Give it some time.

Let it grow like a baby. Don’t rush.

As Gary Vee says,

“Micro speed and macro patience”

Be fast in taking actions in your day to day life, however, keep immense patience over how you do in your entire life.

Enjoy the journey of discovering your purpose and passion in life.
6. Find Your STORY You Want to Tell the World (S)
To conclude what we have discussed so far, you may choose whatever you wish to do.

But always remember what story you want to tell the world.

Imagine Yourself as the Protagonist and Your Life as a Story. Decide what you want to convey.

What kind of qualities do you want to express in this world?

How do you want yourself to be known or be identified by others? (This is not about getting influenced by others’ views but rather what kind of image YOU want to build)

Be brave and bold about it.

Tell me, what kind of a story do you appreciate?

A story where everything is easy and predictable…

Or a story that is difficult to predict, where the hero has to struggle, face challenges and emerge as a winner at the end?

Obviously, the second one.

But when it comes to your own story, you wish it to be like the first one.

That’s not fair 🙂

So, stop worrying.

Look at your life as a great story in making and work for it every day.

Believe me, your life will be more fun, worthwhile and valuable not just for you but others too.
And whenever you wonder again about how to find your purpose and passion in life…
Remember this acronym: P.A.R.F.A.S.

fields.title: How to Have Life-Changing Insights Whenever You Want
fields.description:
The human mind is basically a giant network.

In our minds, we know individual things. These are the nodes of our network. Then, we connect each thing we know to an uncountable amount of other things we know. Each node has thousands of connections to other nodes, forming millions of connections. All of these nodes, and the connections between them, form a network of all the things we know — our knowledge network.

If you’ve ever let your mind wander, moving from one thought to the next in an idle way, you’ve taken a joyride down your own knowledge network.

Most of the time, our knowledge network grows organically. New growth paths emerge along the edge, causing it to grow a little every day.

As we learn more about different subjects, clusters of knowledge begin to form. All the things we know about a topic, like “living in an RV,” form their own cluster. All the things we know about software engineering form another.

Then, our minds link related knowledge clusters together. “RV living” and “minimalism” are related to each other, so there are a lot of connections between them. “RV living” and “software engineering” don’t have much to do with each other, though, so they don’t have many connections. If you were to let your mind wander, it would stop at many stops between RV living and software engineering.
Insights are new connections between clusters.

An insight isn’t just any old new connection.

An insight is a new connection between two clusters that previously didn’t have anything to do with each other.

This single connection acts as a bridge, allowing dozens more to form in its wake. This instant formation of hundreds of new connections produces the heady rush of understanding accompanying an insight.

Most people think they can’t do anything to trigger insight. They think epiphanies just come out of the clear blue sky. As a result, they don’t experience insight often.

But flashes of insight are not out of your control. You don’t have to wait for them to come to you. You can teach your mind to make these connections far more often.

There’s only one thing you have to do.
Read more books — and read them right.

Every book is its own cluster of information. Each chapter, paragraph, and sentence is a new node of information.

As you read more books, you form more clusters of information. As you form more clusters of knowledge, you create more opportunities for clusters and nodes to link together.

But you have to be careful. You can’t just read books any old way. You have to read them carefully and take in what they say.

Storytime: In a past life, I was very Christian. I was a well-educated one, too; not only did I read Christian classics like C.S. Lewis and Lee Strobel, I also read books by dead guys like Saint Augustine.

Not wanting to be accused of a shallow understanding of the world, I also made a point of reading atheist works like those by The Four Horsemen of Atheism.

But none of these books, atheist or Christian, expanded my worldview even one iota.

Why? Because I read them with an agenda.

    When I read pro-Christian books, I didn’t question them. When they made a pretty-sounding argument, I accepted it uncritically.
    When I read anti-Christian books, I immediately engaged every intellectual faculty I have in refuting them.

It took me a shamefully long time to realize most people regard highly that which confirms their biases and shy away from that which does not.

So, while I may have read every book discussing Christianity that came out from 2000 to 2015, I might as well not have read any, because all they did was add to my cluster called “Christianity is right and atheism is wrong.”

You can only learn from books and form new connections if you’re reading to learn. Reading for fun, reading for specific research, and reading to satisfy an agenda all cause you to filter more information. You have fewer insights as a result.
Start reading now, because insights take time.

It takes time reading for conceptual networks of information to start forming in your head. A lot of time.

Last year, I read 82 books, and I didn’t begin to regularly feel the now-familiar rush of understanding until book 60. Now, after 120 books, I feel that rush of understanding several times per book.

A larger network of information means each book can make more connections within my knowledge network. Concepts that would have wowed me at book thirty now seem to be only a small part of a much larger picture.

The big ideas haven’t gotten any smaller, but like overlooking a city from a cliff, I now have a much better vantage point.

When I recall my life before reading, it was like I was stumbling around, drunk and blind. Thanks to books (lots and lots of books), my eyes are starting to open.
Want More Great Articles?

If you want to read more thought-provoking articles like this one, my weekly digest is just the thing for you.
